page.title: 19Strensall - Local History
page.content: The village of Strensall existed before the{Norman Conquest,}but no church was mentioned in the{Domesday {Survey}as it was probably built between 1100 and 1150 A.D. In 1886 {Strensall Common}was purchased by the Government. By 1804 Strensall was on the{Foss Canal}to Sheriff Hutton. The Ship Inn is near the old Strensall Landing. {Strensall Feast}used to be held there. Early{industries}included two potteries (about 1840 onwards) and a tannery (before 1870) which still operates. Farming, the railway and domestic service occupied most people in the 1851 census.{Robert Wilkinson, a batchelor farmer, endowed three charities on his death in 1718. These still operate. The school and the road opposite bear his name. {Old {names}were Strenshale, Stranessale, Strencile, Strencham, Trencham.
